articles.title: Pandemic PhDs: graduates anxious, but optimistic, about the future
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04152-8Five early-career scientists from around the world share how lingering COVID-19 pandemic shadows and ripples from US academic disruptions have affected them.
articles.content:
Last year, Nature’s careers team spoke to five recent PhD students in North America, Israel and the United Kingdom to understand how disruptions, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, had affected their career plans. At the time, these students expressed anxiety about their prospects as they prepared to enter the job market — citing concerns around substantial cuts to US scientific funding, the war in Gaza and lingering delays to PhD projects caused by the pandemic — but also a strong desire to remain in science.

Class of 2025: five PhD students reveal realigned priorities in wake of COVID and cuts

Now, to get a better sense of the global forces shaping the decisions of recent PhD students, Nature has cast a wider net, inviting people in Australia, South Korea, Germany, South Africa and China to share their career journeys. Five students explain how the shadow of COVID-19 continues to shape their careers, and how the chaos of US President Donald Trump’s second administration has reverberated across academia, disrupting plans and shifting priorities far beyond the United States. Still, these students remain optimistic about their prospects, with several pursuing opportunities abroad before they return to their home countries to build careers and, ultimately, support those of other early-career researchers.

YUNHEE KIM: Supporting Korea’s next generation

Will earn her PhD in stem-cell and cancer biology in August from Seoul National University in South Korea.

I started my PhD in stem-cell and cancer biology about six years ago at Pohang University of Science and Technology in South Korea, but, in 2022, my adviser moved to Seoul National University, and I followed him there. Fortunately, the impacts of COVID-19 were not as serious in South Korea as they were in other countries because we didn’t have a heavy lockdown. And because I was living on campus, I was free to go to the laboratory. It would have been disastrous if things had been different. There was a mandatory two-week quarantine for people who became ill, and back then I had to culture stem cells and change their medium every day at the same time. Just one day of delayed experiments would have set me back by six months.

I started studying cancer because I have many family members who have had it. I think immunotherapy is one of the most powerful treatments, but the response rate varies among people, and so I’m looking at the differences between people who do and don’t respond. Why is it that certain tumours do not respond to immunotherapy, and is there a way to alter this type of cancer by changing the tumour microenvironment so that it is more similar to that of someone who does respond?

Are these the happiest PhD students in the world?

I only have one semester left before I graduate. I’m excited because it’s been seven years since I started to discuss this project with my adviser as an undergraduate student. When I first joined his lab, I was not used to reading and writing in English, so it was hard to even read articles to learn more. I’m proud to see the results, after years of struggling.

In my field, clinical translation is important, and so I was interested in exploring how my work can be turned into a real therapy. But because the underlying mechanism is more interesting to me, I decided to do postdoctoral basic research instead. I’d like to go abroad, ideally to the United States, because many of the big names in my field are there and there is a better culture of working with clinicians than there is in Korea. I’d also like to experience a different culture.

In Korea, visible outputs such as publications are strongly tied to securing research funding. Because of this, short-term goals and measurable metrics often become a priority. I sometimes feel this structure limits our ability to pursue more-difficult, long-term or time-intensive scientific questions, or to grow as researchers by tackling more-fundamental challenges. I wonder how other countries deal with these kinds of problems.

Eventually, I’d like to return to Korea to run my own group and help students like me. During my research, I often had concerns about whether it was right for me, and if I could see myself doing it for the rest of my life. Under different circumstances, I might easily have left science. Such concerns are sometimes shared more easily with someone who is close to you, or someone who resembles you, and so I want to work with our country’s students so that they know they have a place in science.

Manan Shah wants to work in research support services with scientists in India.Credit: Lisa Wolany on behalf of Manan Shah

MANAN SHAH: Seeking a research support role

Defended his PhD in biodiversity at the University of Duisburg-Essen in Germany in February 2025.

I experimented with the corporate world after my master’s degree in 2015. But in India, where I’m from, people with a master’s usually end up working in quality assurance. God knows the number of nights I’ve spent resetting passwords and debugging data banks. I soon realized that research is better, and after a few years working in a research position, in 2020 I decided to take a leap and start a PhD at the University of Duisburg-Essen in Germany.

My dissertation focused on analysing water quality in 250 lakes across Europe. With my colleagues, I extracted the complete set of genetic material from the environment, known as the metagenome, to see how varying conditions affect microbial communities. We also did experiments in the lab using artificial rivers to test specific hypotheses. In India, most of the drinking water is not very good quality, and I wanted to do something that would alleviate that problem.

During my PhD, I started thinking ahead to what I wanted to do next. In 2022, a collaborative research centre opened at my university, and my supervisor gave me the opportunity to become a data steward. I interact with different projects to see what type of data researchers are generating, help them to analyse the information and ensure that they’re storing it in a manner that conforms to funding-agency rules. The partnerships I made there allowed me to secure a postdoc with another lab head to develop methods for extracting DNA using a new liquid-handling robot.

Because I’m on a visa that is tied to my employment and I want to stay in Germany, navigating the visa system has been challenging. I’ve been hesitant to leave the country because I’m worried I won’t be allowed back in — which means I haven’t seen my family much.

My goal is to spend five years as a postdoc in Germany. When I come back to India, hopefully with a stronger work portfolio, I’d like to provide research services to scientists there. There are a lot of researchers in India, but not a lot of support staff, and I enjoy jumping into projects, learning about them and problem solving. That type of freedom, in which I get to have a say in what type of research I want to do, is very important for me.

Dezhou Cao is pursuing a physics PhD.Credit: Dezhou Cao

DEZHOU CAO: Pressured to progress

Will graduate in March with a PhD in physics from the Harbin Institute of Technology in China.

I started my PhD in China in 2021, and I’m now finishing my last year as a visiting student at the University of Barcelona in Spain. I applied for a fellowship that supports academic exchanges between China and Spain, and it has been a unique experience. In China, I focused on chemically active colloids — mixtures in which microscopic particles are suspended in a substance — in micro- and nanorobotics. I studied how those particles self-propel, rotate and self-assemble. In Barcelona, I’m learning about condensed matter that relates to how much force is generated when micromotors rotate.

Experiencing a different culture has also been good. In China, we work the whole day, sometimes more than 12 hours. But in Barcelona, I’m more relaxed. I start work at 10:00 and finish around 16:00.

Soon, I will go back to China to write my dissertation, and I’m preparing a two-year postdoctoral research plan in the lab in which I did my PhD. Afterwards, I’d like to find another position in Europe, because physics research is much stronger there than in China. Eventually, I want to run my own lab in China because I’m already adapted to the fast-paced research environment. I would also like to stay close to my parents because I’m an only child, so it’s up to me to look after them.

I am hopeful about starting a lab in China, but there’s a huge pressure. When you are hired, you undergo a three-year assessment period, during which you need to publish a certain number of papers and successfully apply for at least one national research project or grant. If an assistant professor fails to meet these targets, they risk being dismissed. That’s stressful for younger researchers. In China, researchers are also subject to age restrictions that usually don’t exist in Europe and the United States. Some universities set an explicit upper age limit of 35 (and in some cases, 32) for hiring young faculty or research staff. I’m 29, so I feel a lot of pressure to keep making progress.

Nxalati Mkhombo studies in South Africa.Credit: Nxalati

NXALATI MKHOMBO: Keeping an open mind for next steps

Plans to submit her dissertation in molecular and cell biology at the University of Cape Town in South Africa this month.

articles.personality_title: Early-career scientists worldwide navigate challenges with hope and determination
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The COVID-19 pandemic and political events, such as disruptions in US funding and global conflicts, have made it harder for recent PhD graduates to plan their careers. These challenges affected their research timelines and job opportunities.

**What happened** – Nature interviewed several recent PhD students from countries including South Korea, Germany, China, and South Africa. They shared how the pandemic and other global issues changed their work and future plans. Despite difficulties, these scientists remain hopeful and committed to their fields. For example, Yunhee Kim from South Korea continued her cancer research with minor COVID disruptions, while Manan Shah from India used his PhD in Germany to support research data management. Dezhou Cao from China experienced different work cultures studying in Spain and plans to start his own lab in China.

**Impact** – These stories show how young scientists adapt to unexpected problems and keep working toward important goals. Their experiences highlight the global nature of science today and the importance of supporting early-career researchers. It also reveals how different countries face unique challenges, like strict age rules in China or visa issues in Germany, shaping how these graduates build their careers.

**What's next step** – Many of these scientists plan to continue postdoctoral research abroad before returning home to lead labs and mentor others. They want to improve their countries’ research environments and help future students navigate similar challenges. Their journeys may encourage changes in how science careers are supported worldwide.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Despite pandemic and political challenges, recent PhD graduates around the world remain optimistic and determined to advance science and support the next generation of researchers.
articles.personality_title_fr: Jeunes chercheurs du monde entier surmontent les défis avec espoir et détermination
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La pandémie de COVID-19 et des événements politiques, comme les coupures de financement aux États-Unis et des conflits mondiaux, ont compliqué la planification de carrière des récents diplômés de doctorat. Ces difficultés ont retardé leurs recherches et leurs opportunités d’emploi.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Nature a interrogé plusieurs jeunes docteurs de pays comme la Corée du Sud, l’Allemagne, la Chine et l’Afrique du Sud. Ils ont expliqué comment la pandémie et d’autres problèmes mondiaux ont influencé leur travail et leurs projets futurs. Malgré les obstacles, ces scientifiques restent optimistes et engagés dans leurs domaines. Par exemple, Yunhee Kim en Corée du Sud a poursuivi ses recherches sur le cancer avec peu d’interruptions dues au COVID, tandis que Manan Shah en Allemagne a soutenu la gestion des données de recherche. Dezhou Cao, en Chine, a découvert une culture de travail différente en Espagne et prévoit de créer son propre laboratoire.

**Impact** – Ces récits montrent comment les jeunes chercheurs s’adaptent aux imprévus et avancent vers leurs objectifs. Ils illustrent la dimension mondiale de la science aujourd’hui et l’importance d’aider les chercheurs en début de carrière. Ils révèlent aussi les défis spécifiques à chaque pays, comme les limites d’âge en Chine ou les problèmes de visa en Allemagne, qui influencent leur parcours.

**Prochaines étapes** – Beaucoup envisagent de poursuivre des recherches postdoctorales à l’étranger avant de revenir diriger des laboratoires et accompagner d’autres étudiants. Ils veulent améliorer la recherche dans leur pays et aider les futurs chercheurs à surmonter des difficultés similaires. Leur expérience pourrait encourager des changements dans le soutien aux carrières scientifiques dans le monde.

**Une phrase clé** – Malgré les défis liés à la pandémie et à la politique, les jeunes docteurs du monde entier restent déterminés et optimistes pour faire progresser la science et soutenir la prochaine génération de chercheurs.
articles.personality_title_es: Jóvenes científicos de todo el mundo enfrentan desafíos con esperanza y determinación
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La pandemia de COVID-19 y eventos políticos, como recortes en fondos científicos en EE. UU. y conflictos globales, dificultaron que los recién graduados de doctorado planificaran sus carreras. Estos problemas retrasaron sus investigaciones y oportunidades laborales.

**Qué sucedió** – Nature entrevistó a varios jóvenes doctores de países como Corea del Sur, Alemania, China y Sudáfrica. Contaron cómo la pandemia y otros problemas mundiales afectaron su trabajo y planes futuros. A pesar de las dificultades, estos científicos mantienen la esperanza y el compromiso con sus áreas. Por ejemplo, Yunhee Kim de Corea del Sur continuó su investigación sobre el cáncer con pocas interrupciones por COVID, mientras que Manan Shah en Alemania apoyó la gestión de datos de investigación. Dezhou Cao de China vivió una cultura laboral distinta en España y planea crear su propio laboratorio.

**Impacto** – Estas historias muestran cómo los jóvenes investigadores se adaptan a problemas inesperados y siguen avanzando hacia sus metas. Destacan la naturaleza global de la ciencia hoy y la importancia de apoyar a los investigadores en etapas tempranas. También revelan desafíos únicos de cada país, como límites de edad en China o problemas de visa en Alemania, que influyen en sus carreras.

**Próximos pasos** – Muchos planean continuar con investigaciones postdoctorales en el extranjero antes de regresar para dirigir laboratorios y apoyar a otros estudiantes. Quieren mejorar la investigación en sus países y ayudar a futuros investigadores a enfrentar dificultades similares. Sus experiencias podrían impulsar cambios en el apoyo a las carreras científicas a nivel mundial.

**Una frase clave** – A pesar de los retos de la pandemia y la política, los jóvenes doctores de todo el mundo permanecen optimistas y decididos a avanzar en la ciencia y apoyar a la próxima generación de investigadores.

articles.title: The Bulgarian Stock Exchange marked the first trading session in euro with an official ceremony
articles.summary: The first transactions in the new currency are a fact, and the main index SOFIX reports an increase
articles.content:
The first transactions in the new currency are a fact, and the main index SOFIX reports an increase

SOFIA – The first session of the Bulgarian Stock Exchange (BSE) with trading in euros was officially marked with a ceremony in the BSE building in Sofia. After Bulgaria’s accession to the eurozone on 1 January 2026, the Bulgarian capital market now operates entirely in the single European currency for all exchange-traded instruments.

According to Vasil Golemanski, Chairman of the Financial Supervision Commission, today has historical significance for the capital market, the economy and the country as a whole.

With Bulgaria’s admission to the eurozone, the Bulgarian economy is fully integrated into the European one, Golemanski said.

He emphasized that the BSE’s turnover for 2025 has passed the threshold of 1 billion leva and expressed the wish that in the current 2026 it will exceed 1 billion euros.

Asen Yagodin, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the BSE, pointed out that the adoption of the euro is something that our country has been waiting for 28 years under a currency board regime. According to him, the board has contributed to the stability of public finances and has allowed the country to accumulate reserves and maintain low levels of indebtedness.

With entry into the eurozone and the redenomination of all our exchange-traded instruments into euros, it is expected that the investors we lost in 2009-2010, foreign investors, as well as Bulgarian ones, will return to our market, Yagodin said.

The Executive Director of the BSE Manyu Moravenov expressed confidence that years of growth lie ahead for the Bulgarian capital market.

The Bulgarian Stock Exchange is already a European platform on which good ideas find capital and good companies find growth. I am convinced that a new investment cycle is starting for the Bulgarian capital market of growth, of trust and of many more opportunities for integration, Moravenov said.

He notes that trading on the BSE in euros has already started and the first transactions in the new currency are a fact, while the main index SOFIX is reporting an increase of 2 percent since the beginning of the day.

The Executive Director of the BSE stated that this year the first simultaneous initial public offering (IPO) procedure on the BSE and on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange via the Eurobridge segment is also expected. (5.01.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on Bulgaria's successful integration into the eurozone with the Bulgarian Stock Exchange conducting its first trading session in euros. This marks a significant economic milestone with broad positive implications for the country's economy, investor confidence, and capital market growth. The story focuses clearly on this major transition and its expected benefits, including attracting foreign investment and fostering economic stability and growth.
articles.personality_title: Bulgaria’s stock market begins trading in euros after joining eurozone
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Bulgaria joined the eurozone on January 1, 2026, which means it now uses the euro as its official currency. Until this change, the Bulgarian Stock Exchange traded mainly in the national currency, leva.

**What happened** – The Bulgarian Stock Exchange (BSE) held its first official trading session using the euro. This event was marked by a ceremony in Sofia, the capital city. During this session, stocks and other financial instruments were traded in euros for the first time, and the main stock index, called SOFIX, rose by 2 percent.

**Impact** – Trading in euros makes Bulgaria’s stock market part of the larger European financial system. This change is expected to attract more foreign and local investors who avoided the market in the past. It also reflects the country’s economic stability and growth, supported by years of careful financial management. In 2025, the BSE’s total trading volume passed 1 billion leva, and now it aims to reach over 1 billion euros.

**What’s next step** – The Bulgarian Stock Exchange plans to introduce new investment opportunities, including a joint stock sale (called an initial public offering or IPO) with the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in Germany. This will help Bulgarian companies connect with more investors in Europe and support further market growth.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Bulgaria’s switch to euro trading on its stock exchange marks a key step toward stronger ties with Europe and a more attractive market for investors.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Bourse de Bulgarie commence à trader en euros après l’entrée dans la zone euro
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Bulgarie a rejoint la zone euro le 1er janvier 2026, ce qui signifie qu’elle utilise désormais l’euro comme monnaie officielle. Avant ce changement, la Bourse bulgare négociait principalement en leva, la monnaie nationale.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La Bourse de Bulgarie (BSE) a tenu sa première séance officielle de négociation en euros. Cet événement a été marqué par une cérémonie à Sofia, la capitale. Lors de cette séance, les actions et autres instruments financiers ont été échangés en euros pour la première fois, et l’indice principal, appelé SOFIX, a augmenté de 2 %.

**Impact** – Le passage à l’euro intègre la Bourse bulgare dans le système financier européen plus large. Ce changement devrait attirer plus d’investisseurs étrangers et locaux qui évitaient le marché auparavant. Il reflète aussi la stabilité et la croissance économique du pays, soutenues par une gestion financière prudente. En 2025, le volume total des échanges à la BSE a dépassé 1 milliard de leva, et l’objectif est maintenant d’atteindre plus d’1 milliard d’euros.

**Prochaine étape** – La Bourse bulgare prévoit d’introduire de nouvelles opportunités d’investissement, dont une offre publique initiale (OPI) conjointe avec la Bourse de Francfort en Allemagne. Cela permettra aux entreprises bulgares de se connecter à plus d’investisseurs en Europe et favorisera la croissance du marché.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le passage à la négociation en euros à la Bourse de Bulgarie est une étape clé vers des liens plus forts avec l’Europe et un marché plus attractif pour les investisseurs.
articles.personality_title_es: La bolsa de Bulgaria comienza a operar en euros tras unirse a la eurozona
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Bulgaria se unió a la eurozona el 1 de enero de 2026, lo que significa que ahora usa el euro como moneda oficial. Antes de este cambio, la Bolsa de Bulgaria operaba principalmente con la moneda nacional, el leva.

**Qué pasó** – La Bolsa de Valores de Bulgaria (BSE) realizó su primera sesión oficial de negociación en euros. Este evento se celebró con una ceremonia en Sofía, la capital. Durante esta sesión, las acciones y otros instrumentos financieros se negociaron en euros por primera vez, y el índice principal, llamado SOFIX, subió un 2 %.

**Impacto** – Operar en euros integra la bolsa búlgara al sistema financiero europeo más amplio. Se espera que este cambio atraiga a más inversores extranjeros y locales que antes evitaban el mercado. También muestra la estabilidad y crecimiento económico del país, gracias a una gestión financiera cuidadosa. En 2025, el volumen total de operaciones en la BSE superó los 1.000 millones de leva, y ahora se espera superar los 1.000 millones de euros.

**Próximo paso** – La Bolsa de Bulgaria planea ofrecer nuevas oportunidades de inversión, incluyendo una oferta pública inicial (OPI) conjunta con la Bolsa de Frankfurt en Alemania. Esto ayudará a las empresas búlgaras a conectar con más inversores en Europa y apoyará el crecimiento del mercado.

**Resumen en una frase** – El cambio a la negociación en euros en la bolsa búlgara es un paso clave para fortalecer los lazos con Europa y crear un mercado más atractivo para los inversores.
